steps.title: See if the cockroach is at least 1 1⁄2 in (3.8 cm) long.
steps.content: See if the cockroach is at least 1 1 ⁄ 2 in (3.8 cm) long. Estimate how long the critter is—typically, American cockroaches are about 1 1 ⁄ 2 to 2 in (3.8 to 5.1 cm) long. They’re very large compared to other types of roaches. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Recognize the brown or red-brown color of the roach.
steps.content: Recognize the brown or red-brown color of the roach. American cockroaches are unique from other cockroaches in that they have a red-brown color that has an amber look to it. Most other cockroaches are a muddy brown color. Check to see if the roach you are looking at has a reddish glow to it. [2] X Research source In some cases, American cockroaches are a chocolate-brown color instead of the usual red-brown.

steps.title: Spot a shiny exterior.
steps.content: Spot a shiny exterior. Aside from their unique color, American cockroaches are also quite shiny. Their exterior, including their body and wings, has a shiny quality to it that many call glossy but no one would call glamorous.[Image:Identify a Cockroach Step 3 Version 3.jpg|center]]

steps.title: Check if it’s munching on wet food.
steps.content: Check if it’s munching on wet food. American cockroaches are notorious for only eating moist, fermenting food, which can make them a big household problem. If you see a large cockroach eating something damp, it is very likely that it is an American cockroach. [3] X Research source For instance, an American cockroach might snack on a slice of old bread soaked with beer in the trash.

steps.title: Search for a brown or black egg casing.
steps.content: Search for a brown or black egg casing. American cockroaches lay their eggs in a large, cylindrical egg case. If the egg casing is new, then it’ll be brown—after 1-2 days, it’ll look black. The female cockroaches like to drop the casings in less obvious spots where they won’t be in the way, so you might not see them.

steps.title: Observe if it’s hanging out in a damp area.
steps.content: Observe if it’s hanging out in a damp area. American cockroaches love warm, humid spots that are at least 82 °F (28 °C). You might spot an American cockroach in your basement, or hanging out somewhere near the ground floor. [4] X Research source These critters also like to hang out in garbage dumps, sewers, and other similar areas.

steps.title: Look for wings on a fully-grown cockroach.
steps.content: Look for wings on a fully-grown cockroach. American cockroaches don’t have wings while they’re still developing, but they have a pair of long wings by the time they’re adults. If you see a large bug flying in your home, it might be an American cockroach. [5] X Research source These wings are long—a male cockroach’s wings are slightly longer than their body.

steps.title: Observe if the cockroach is 1⁄2 in (1.3 cm) long.
steps.content: Observe if the cockroach is 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) long. German cockroaches aren’t as huge as some of their brethren, but they’re big enough to spot with the naked eye. Typically, they’re somewhere between 1 ⁄ 2 and 5 ⁄ 8 in (1.3 and 1.6 cm) long once they’re fully grown. [6] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Look for 2 dark stripes on its back.
steps.content: Look for 2 dark stripes on its back. This critter is best recognized by the two parallel lines that run from the back of the cockroach’s head down to its wings. The stripes or lines are dark brown in color and can appear almost black. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Check to see if the roach is near water.
steps.content: Check to see if the roach is near water. German cockroaches love moist, warm areas. You can generally find them in your kitchen or bathroom, lurking next to the dishwasher or sink. They are also notoriously present in garbage, which is where they find most of their food. [8] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Some cockroaches also like to hang out near especially warm areas, like toaster ovens. [9] X Research source

steps.title: See if it’s hiding out in a crack or crevice.
steps.content: See if it’s hiding out in a crack or crevice. German cockroaches are very small, and can squeeze into different hiding places, such as crevices near a sink or toilet. They’re also great at hiding beneath appliances, like dishwashers, stoves, and refrigerators. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Spot these cockroaches traveling through most openings.
steps.content: Spot these cockroaches traveling through most openings. These critters are really small, and can enter your home just about anywhere. You might see them traveling along the walls or ceilings, or they might travel along the pipes and wires to get from point A to point B. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Search for a large group of roaches in 1 area.
steps.content: Search for a large group of roaches in 1 area. German cockroaches reproduce much more quickly than other cockroaches, so you’ll probably see a lot of these little guys in 1 place. If it looks like you have an infestation, you might be dealing with German cockroaches. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Recognize this cockroach eating almost anything.
steps.content: Recognize this cockroach eating almost anything. German cockroaches aren’t picky eaters, and will munch on most edible things in your home. You might see them eating human food, or they might be nibbling on toothpaste, soap, leftover hair, or other filth. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Look for a cylindrical, brown egg case.
steps.content: Look for a cylindrical, brown egg case. You might not see these egg casings lying around your home—the female cockroach tends to keep them with her up until the eggs hatch. Each case holds at least 30 eggs. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Check if the cockroach is at least 1 in (2.5 cm) long.
steps.content: Check if the cockroach is at least 1 in (2.5 cm) long. Oriental cockroaches are somewhere between 1 and 1 1 ⁄ 4 in (2.5 and 3.2 cm) long, which makes them bigger than German cockroaches but smaller than American ones. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Recognize the dark color of the roach.
steps.content: Recognize the dark color of the roach. Oriental cockroaches are known for their deep brown color. In certain lights, this sort of cockroach can actually appear black. Other than their unique coloring, the Oriental cockroach doesn’t have any distinguishing markings.

steps.title: Notice the wings on the Oriental cockroach.
steps.content: Notice the wings on the Oriental cockroach. Female Oriental cockroaches have very short wings, while male cockroaches have slightly longer wings that don’t cover their entire body. However, despite the fact that they have wings, these cockroaches can’t fly. [16] X Research source

steps.title: See if the cockroach is in a moist area.
steps.content: See if the cockroach is in a moist area. Oriental cockroaches can survive a long, cold winter outside, and can survive in freezing cold temperatures. [17] X Research source They tend to hang out in moist cellars, basement drains, and shady yards. You might also find them under rocks, random debris, and old leaves.

steps.title: Catch them snacking on all kinds of food.
steps.content: Catch them snacking on all kinds of food. You might spot an Oriental cockroach hanging out near your garbage. They like munching on any type of organic food, and aren’t picky eaters. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Look for a round, dark egg casing.
steps.content: Look for a round, dark egg casing. Oriental cockroach egg cases are dark brown and cylindrically shaped. [19] X Research source You’ll probably spot them in a secluded, out-of-the-way place, instead of out in the open.

steps.title: Spot these cockroaches entering through different openings.
steps.content: Spot these cockroaches entering through different openings. Oriental cockroaches tend to travel through air ducts, vents, and garbage chutes, which might be how they enter your home. Some are craft enough to come beneath your door, too. [20] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Sometimes, Oriental cockroaches can enter your home through a food package, or they might hitch a ride on your laundry. Oriental cockroaches are usually found near the ground floor, instead of higher floors. [21] X Research source

steps.title: Search for a small, 1⁄2 in (1.3 cm) long critter in your home.
steps.content: Search for a small, 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) long critter in your home. Brown-banded cockroaches grow to be about 1 ⁄ 2 in (1.3 cm) long. They are one of the smallest varieties of cockroaches. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Look for a yellow-brown band around its abdomen.
steps.content: Look for a yellow-brown band around its abdomen. Contrary to what you might think, the brown-banded cockroach is actually named for a yellow band that can be found on the bug. Search for two bands—there should be a very thick one at the bottom of the abdomen, and a thinner band running across the mid-abdomen area. [23] X Research source

steps.title: Scope out warm areas where they might hang out.
steps.content: Scope out warm areas where they might hang out. Brown-banded cockroaches generally live in places with warmer climates. If you are having a cockroach problem but live in a humid, mid- or low-temperature climate, you are probably dealing with another kind of cockroach. [24] X Research source For reference, brown-banded cockroaches like places that are warmer than 80 °F (27 °C).

steps.title: Search for any water sources nearby.
steps.content: Search for any water sources nearby. Brown-banded cockroaches aren’t a fan of water—as such, they are not often found near any sort of water source. If you have found a cockroach living near your sink or toilet, it is more than likely not a brown-banded cockroach. [25] X Research source

steps.title: Watch if the cockroach flies away.
steps.content: Watch if the cockroach flies away. Unlike the other cockroaches, the brown-banded cockroach will fly off if disturbed. If you notice a small cockroach flying through the air, chances are it is a brown-banded cockroach. [26] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Look for a round, brown egg case along the bottom of different surfaces.
steps.content: Look for a round, brown egg case along the bottom of different surfaces. Brown-banded cockroaches tend to attach their egg cases to different surfaces, instead of hiding them in a secluded spot. You might see these egg casings, on the ceiling, stuck behind a drawer, slipped beneath furniture, nestled in a closet, or in another dark spot.

steps.title: Catch these cockroaches eating just about anything.
steps.content: Catch these cockroaches eating just about anything. Unlike other cockroaches, the brown-banded variety likes to eat random items, like envelopes, old paper, drapes, wallpaper, stockings, and other materials. These critters also enjoy eating glue. [27] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Check any firewood you brought home recently.
steps.content: Check any firewood you brought home recently. Unlike other types, Pennsylvania wood cockroaches don’t typically wander indoors. However, you might find some lurking on a pile of firewood that you bring into your home—these roaches love to hang out there. [28] X Research source This type of cockroach also hangs out near logs and tree branches. If there’s any wood near your windows, this critter might fly into your home when the window is open.

steps.title: See if the roach is less than 1 in (2.5 cm) long.
steps.content: See if the roach is less than 1 in (2.5 cm) long. Pennsylvania wood roaches are between 1 ⁄ 2 and 1 in (1.3 and 2.5 cm) long. They aren’t huge compared to some types of roaches, but you’ll still be able to spot them in your home. [29] X Research source

steps.title: Look for a dark brown color with yellow tints.
steps.content: Look for a dark brown color with yellow tints. Most Pennsylvania wood cockroaches are dark brown, with yellow highlights near the head and wings. [30] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Due to their coloring, it’s easy to mix these critters up with Oriental roaches. [31] X Research source Oriental roaches don’t have any yellow coloring near their heads.

steps.title: Observe if the critter flies away.
steps.content: Observe if the critter flies away. Like their brown-banded brethren, Pennsylvania wood cockroaches can also fly. The male roaches have a full set of wings that’s longer than their bodies, while females have really short wings that don’t actually allow them to fly. [32] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Spot these cockroaches eating decaying matter.
steps.content: Spot these cockroaches eating decaying matter. Pennsylvania wood cockroaches don’t usually come inside, and like to eat rotting wood and other organic materials. [33] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Look for curved, yellow-brown egg capsules.
steps.content: Look for curved, yellow-brown egg capsules. These cockroaches tend to drop off their egg capsules behind old, fallen logs, tree stumps, or loose bark. These capsules are much longer than they are wide, and have a slight curve to them. [34] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source
